text: Amanda Yarnell: My hope is that, in the future, C&EN will continue to drive conversation in chemistry.

Bibiana Campos Seijo: C&EN is a global brand
and I would like to make it as impactful as
it can be in a global arena.

Lauren Wolf: Journalism is changing so much
and I think it can be kind of overwhelming

sometimes, but at the same time, it's also
exhilarating.

Campos Seijo: The life of a journalist has
changed a lot, it's not just about producing

great content. But it's also about the promotion
of that content through social media, for

example, which now journalists do lots of
interactions in that area.

Rob Bryson: I'm excited by the work that the
design department is doing, some of the digital-first

things, the interactive graphics that we're
working on, the opportunities that we're going
to have to for those types of things.

Matt Davenport: What's been really exciting
to me working here is that we're not waiting

to see what happens, we're going out there
and trying new stuff.

Campos Seijo: I think we're going to be in
a very good place when it comes to the 100th

anniversary. I think it's going to be bigger
and better than ever before.

Wolf: There's so many different places to
go and I'm excited to be part of that, being

able to drive the magazine in whatever direction
it goes.

Yarnell: My dream for the future is that we
continue to tell stories that people can't

put down, that they want to talk to their
fellow chemists about. And maybe even inspire

you to go back and do something differently
at the bench.
